data: Defines lexical sources based on WordNet, assigning sentiment scores (objective, positive, negative) to individual word meanings (synsets).

Contains almost 5,000 text snippets, collected from financial news and press releases about Finnish companies traded on the NASDAQ OMX Nordic Stock Exchange. Each text snippet is labeled as positive, negative, or neutral.
A dataset for understanding sentiment in financial text, combining artificial intelligence and Semantic Web technologies to better recognize, interpret, and process opinions in this context.

Includes entity-sentiment annotations to address the challenge of headlines containing multiple entities with conflicting sentiment potential. This human-annotated dataset of over 10,700 news headlines provides insight into sentiment variations dependent on specific entities in financial news.

A tokenized and annotated dataset of speeches, meeting minutes, and press conference transcripts of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC). This source aims to understand the impact of monetary policy on financial markets by analyzing the language used by central banks.

A dataset of relation annotations in financial documents with approximately 29,000 instances and 22 relation types across eight entity pairs (e.g., person-title, org-money), extracted from SEC 10-X filings. Useful for identifying relationships between entities in financial reports.
Compiled from various news sources and evaluated by human experts, allowing researchers to explore how news headlines affect price movements, asset ratios, and other financial events.
A dataset designed for Named Entity Recognition (NER) in the financial landscape, assisting in identifying and classifying financial companies in text data.

Provides a multilingual financial NLP dataset with real-world financial article headlines in 15 languages. Annotated with high-level and low-level topics, facilitating multi-class and multi-label classification tasks.

A collection of question-answer pairs with deep analysis of financial reports. Written by financial experts, focusing on deep reasoning about financial data, providing training data for answering complex financial questions.
